channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indiana Senate Republicans Reject Trump’s Redistricting Effort
item.description: Republicans hold an overwhelming majority in the Indiana Senate, but more than a dozen of them defied the president’s wishes, voting against a map aimed at adding Republicans in Congress.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Legislators at the Indiana Statehouse on Thursday as discussion over a proposed political map was underway.

item.title: Republicans Undercut Johnson, Circumventing Him to Force Votes
item.description: The speaker has repeatedly lost his grip on the House floor thanks to a once rare parliamentary maneuver that G.O.P. members are increasingly using to force action on legislation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson’s hold on his razor-thin majority has become increasingly slippery, as rank-and-file Republicans flout his wishes.

item.title: Key Takeaways After Indiana Lawmakers Defy Trump’s Redistricting Push
item.description: President Trump’s failure to ram through a Republican-friendly House map was a new sign that his iron grip on the party has slipped, and was likely to reverberate nationally.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republican members of the Indiana Senate voted on Thursday to reject an effort led by President Trump to pass a congressional map that would have given the party two extra House seats.

item.title: Senate Deadlocks Over Obamacare Subsidies in Dueling Votes
item.description: Republicans blocked Democrats’ effort to extend the expiring subsidies while Democrats thwarted a G.O.P. proposal to replace them with direct payments for basic health coverage.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator John Thune, Republican of South Dakota and the majority leader, at the Capitol this week.

item.title: A Grand Jury Again Resists Trump’s Push to Reindict Letitia James
item.description: It was a striking rejection of the administration’s retribution campaign.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, Devlin Barrett and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Letitia James, New York’s attorney general, and President Trump have clashed for years, in part because of the civil suit she brought against him, his company and his family members.

item.title: China Is Getting Much of What It Wants From the U.S., Including Chips
item.description: For China, President Trump’s moves to loosen chip controls, soften U.S. rhetoric and stay silent on tensions with Japan amount to a rare string of strategic gains.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, after their meeting in Busan, South Korea, in October. Mr. Trump’s latest moves extended the conciliatory posture he struck at this summit.

item.title: Trump Moves to Stop States From Regulating AI With a New Executive Order
item.description: The order would create one federal regulatory framework for artificial intelligence, President Trump told reporters in the Oval Office.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, who has said it’s important for America to dominate in the race to develop A.I., has said that the various state A.I. laws have created a confusing patchwork of regulations.

item.title: Can OpenAI Respond After Google Closes the A.I. Technology Gap?
item.description: A new technology release from OpenAI is supposed to top what Google recently produced. It also shows OpenAI is engaged in a new and more difficult competition.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: OpenAI’s newest technology comes after Google claimed it had topped its young competitor.

item.title: My Favorite Performances of the Year
item.description: Actors took big swings in 2025. Here are some of the best.
item.dc:creator: Wesley Morris and Sasha Weiss

item.title: Ford’s Car of the Future, Hatched in a Skunk Works Near Los Angeles
item.description: Desperate to catch up with Chinese automakers, Ford is redesigning its fleet with a Silicon Valley-style team. Is it too late?
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Field, Ford Motor Company’s chief of electric vehicles, digital and design.

item.title: U.S. Issues New Sanctions Targeting Maduro’s Family and the Oil Sector
item.description: The United States is escalating its pressure campaign on Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, after seizing an oil tanker off the coast.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Tyler Pager, Farnaz Fassihi and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro during a rally in Caracas on Wednesday.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Winner Machado Says U.S. Helped Her Leave Venezuela
item.description: María Corina Machado reappeared on the global stage as the Trump administration ramped up its pressure campaign against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Heiko Junge/NTB, via Reuters
item.media:description: María Corina Machado at a news conference in Oslo, Norway, on Thursday after spending more than a year in hiding.

item.title: What Does the Oil Tanker Seizure Mean for Venezuela’s Economy?
item.description: Seizures of more tankers could put a stranglehold on Venezuela’s economy, which is exceptionally dependent on oil to keep the government running and pay for basic necessities.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker docked at Cardon Refinery in Venezuela, in 2021.

item.title: Bessent Accelerates Regulation Overhaul to Jumpstart Growth
item.description: The Treasury Secretary unveiled changes to the Financial Stability Oversight Council to ease “overregulation.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent argued that financial stability was best achieved through faster economic growth, which he said was constrained by unnecessary regulations.

item.title: S&P 500 Reaches Record High as Stocks Reverse Downturn
item.description: The S&P 500 edged higher as investors shrugged off concerns over Oracle’s earnings. It was just enough.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: U.S. Helped to Weaken Report at U.N. Environment Talks, Participants Say
item.description: American officials joined Russia, Saudi Arabia and Iran in objecting to language on fossils fuels, biodiversity and plastics in a report that was three years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Monicah Mwangi/Reuters
item.media:description: The opening session of the 7th United Nations Environment Assembly in Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks FEMA From Canceling Climate Resiliency Grants
item.description: A Thursday ruling said the Trump administration cannot eliminate the Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities program without Congress.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Ed Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A flood defense project on the East Side of Manhattan in 2021.

item.title: Trump Panel Abruptly Postpones Release of FEMA Overhaul Recommendations
item.description: The group’s report had been expected to provide a road map for change after months of upheaval at the agency.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Reuters
item.media:description: Talk of a FEMA overhaul comes as disasters are becoming more frequent and costly as a result of climate change.

item.title: Zelensky Says Revised U.S. Plan Still Calls for Ukraine to Leave Donbas
item.description: The Ukrainian leader rejected the demand, making clear that territorial issues remain unresolved as Ukraine and Europe sent a counterproposal to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a Russian missile attack in Ternopil, western Ukraine, last month.

item.title: The Hollywood Studio Tour Has Become a Lot of Nothing
item.description: It’s hard to make a movie studio tour exciting when movies aren’t made there anymore. “A vibe of tiredness, like the end of something,” one guest said.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Ricardo Nagaoka
item.media:description: Paramount’s Bronson Gate. David Ellison, the studio’s new owner, has said he will reinvest in the lot and release up to 20 films annually.

item.title: 100,000 in Washington State Ordered to Evacuate as Rivers Rise
item.description: Days of heavy rain pushed waterways to record flood levels in a mountainous region north of Seattle. “Do not wait,” local officials warned residents, urging them to seek higher ground.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin, Amy Graff and Drew Atkins
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Floodwaters poured over Springhetti Road in Snohomish, Wash.

item.title: ‘Storm Highway’ Forecast to Send More Rain to Washington and British Columbia
item.description: Just as this week’s floodwaters in the Pacific Northwest begin to recede, forecasters warn, another storm will approach the West Coast.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Killer Whales Find an ‘Unlikely Friend’ in Dolphins
item.description: Off the coast of British Columbia, dolphins lead killer whales to salmon and earn their share of lunch, a new study reveals.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: America Is Entering Its Third Civil War
item.description: Trump is not interested in refighting the Cold War. He is, in my view, interested in fighting the civilizational war over what is the American “home.”
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Alex Kent for The New York Times

item.title: Life and Death in India’s Air Apocalypse
item.description: For hundreds of millions of Indians, toxic winter air poisons bodies, constricts lives and wears down spirits.
item.dc:creator: Anurag Minus Verma
item.media:credit: Vani Bhushan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hazy skies laden with harmful particulates settle in every winter over vast areas of India such as this congested road in New Delhi.

item.title: Reddit Sues Australian Government to Block Social Media Ban
item.description: The company said the new law, which makes it illegal for children under 16 to have social media accounts, infringes on children’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: School children waiting for a bus in Sydney, last month. The ban took effect on Wednesday.

item.title: Man Accused in Charlie Kirk Killing Makes First Court Appearance in Person
item.description: Tyler Robinson faces murder charges in Utah in the Sept. 10 assassination of Mr. Kirk, the political activist and ally of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rick Egan
item.media:description: Tyler Robinson, accused in the murder of Charlie Kirk, appears during a hearing in Provo, Utah, on Thursday.

item.title: 6 Injured and 2 Missing in Bay Area Neighborhood Gas Explosion
item.description: A gas line explosion in Hayward, Calif., sent multiple victims to the hospital and led to a fire that burned several houses.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla

item.title: Arkansas Public Television Drops PBS
item.description: The loss of federal funding forced a difficult decision, the executive director of Arkansas TV said: Cut PBS, or go off the air entirely.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Kristoffer Tripplaar/Sipa, via AP Images
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Public Broadcasting Service in Arlington, Va.
